title: Question 60

children: A 21-year-old man is evaluated for pharyngitis and a rash.
Examination findings of the throat and
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient most likely has pharyngitis, which presents as sore throat that may worsen with swallowing; symptoms typically last less than 1 week. Physical examination findings that support the diagnosis of streptococcal pharyngitis include palatal petechiae and a scarlatiniform rash, as seen in this patient, and a strawberry tongue.
Features suggesting the more common viral cause include cough, conjunctivitis, coryza, hoarseness, and oral ulcers. Only 5% to 15% of pharyngitis cases are caused by bacteria, most often group A

The Infectious Diseases Society of America suggests that patients with two or fewer Centor criteria (fever by history, tonsillar exudates, tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and absence of cough) do not need to be tested. Patients with three or more Centor criteria should be tested by using a rapid antigen detection test.
